summary.long: 2 Samuel is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: After the death of Saul, when David had returned from defeating the Amalekites, he stayed at Ziklag for two days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then, on the third day, a man arrived from Saul’s camp. His clothing was torn, and there was dirt on his head. When he approached David, he fell to the ground and bowed down to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David said to him, “Where are you coming from?”
He answered, “I have escaped from the camp of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David said to him, “What was the outcome? Tell me!”
The man said, “The people fled from the battle. Many of the people were struck down and died. Even Saul and his son Jonathan have died.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to the young man who was talking to him, “How do you know that Saul and his son Jonathan are dead?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young man who was talking to him said, “I happened to be on Mount Gilboa. There I saw Saul, leaning on his spear. The chariots and charioteers were closing in on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul looked behind him, he saw me and called to me and I answered, ‘I am here.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“He said to me, ‘Who are you?’
“I said to him, ‘I am an Amalekite.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Saul said to me, ‘Please stand beside me and put me to death. I am losing consciousness, but I am still alive.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I stood beside him and ended his life, because I knew that he could not live after being so severely wounded. I took the crown on his head and the armlet on his arm, and I brought them here to my lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and all the men with him grabbed their clothing and tore it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Until evening they mourned, wept, and fasted for Saul, for his son Jonathan, for the people of the Lord, and for the house of Israel, because they had fallen by the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David asked the young man who had told him about Saul, “Where are you from?”
He said, “I am an Amalekite, who lives here as an alien.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David asked him, “Why were you not afraid to stretch out your hand to destroy the Lord’s anointed?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David called to one of the young men, “Come here. Kill him!” He struck him down, and he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “Your blood will be on your own head, because your own mouth testified against you when you said, ‘I have killed the Lord’s anointed.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David mourned with this funeral song about Saul and his son Jonathan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He gave orders to teach the men of Judah this song, which was named “The Bow,” so it was recorded in the Book of Jashar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The splendor of Israel has been slain upon your high places.
How the mighty warriors have fallen!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You must not tell about it in Gath.
You must not publish it in the streets of Ashkelon.
If you do, the daughters of the Philistines will rejoice.
The daughters of the uncircumcised will celebrate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You mountains of Gilboa, may no dew or rain fall on you.
May your fields produce no special offerings.
For there the shield of the mighty was desecrated.
The shield of Saul was not anointed with oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From the blood of the slain,
from the fat of the mighty warriors,
the bow of Jonathan did not turn back,
and the sword of Saul never returned empty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul and Jonathan were the most loved and admired during their lives,
and in their deaths they were not separated.
They were swifter than eagles.
They were stronger than lions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Daughters of Israel, weep over Saul.
He clothed you in scarlet and luxury.
He provided gold ornaments for your clothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How the mighty warriors have fallen in the midst of battle!
Jonathan lies slain on your high places!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I grieve over you, my brother Jonathan!
You were very dear to me.
Your love was more wonderful to me than the love of women.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How the mighty warriors have fallen!
The weapons of war have perished!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
After this, David asked the Lord, “Should I go up into one of the cities of Judah?”
The Lord said to him, “Go up.”
David said, “Where shall I go up?”
The Lord said, “To Hebron.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David went there with his two wives, Ahinoam of Jezre’el and Abigail of Carmel, who was Nabal’s widow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David also brought along the men who were with him, each man together with his household, and they settled in the towns around Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The men of Judah came there and anointed David to be king over the house of Judah.
David was told, “The men of Jabesh Gilead are the ones who buried Saul.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David sent messengers to the men of Jabesh Gilead and said to them, “You are blessed by the Lord because you performed this act of mercy and faithfulness for your master Saul by burying him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now may the Lord deal with you with mercy and faithfulness. I also will treat you well because you have done this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now let your hands be strong and courageous, for your master Saul is dead, and the house of Judah has anointed me to be king over them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, Abner son of Ner, the commander of Saul’s army, had taken Ishbosheth, the son of Saul, to Mahanaim
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and made him king over Gilead, Ashuri, and Jezre’el, and over Ephraim, Benjamin, and all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ishbosheth, Saul’s son, was forty years old when he became king over Israel, and he reigned for two years.
But the house of Judah followed David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was king in Hebron over the house of Judah for seven years and six months.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner son of Ner and the followers of Ishbosheth son of Saul went out from Mahanaim to Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab son of Zeruiah and the followers of David went out and confronted them at the pool of Gibeon. They took up positions on the opposite sides of the pool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Abner said to Joab, “The young men should get up and compete in front of us.”
Joab said, “Yes, let them do so.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So twelve representatives for Benjamin and Ishbosheth son of Saul got up and crossed over to confront twelve representatives for David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each one grabbed his opponent’s head and thrust his sword into his side. Together, they all fell. So that place, which is near Gibeon, was called Helkath Hatsurim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A fierce battle took place that day. Abner and the men of Israel were beaten by the followers of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three sons of Zeruiah were there, namely, Joab, Abishai, and Asahel. Asahel was a fast runner, like one of the gazelles out in the fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asahel pursued Abner and did not turn aside to the right or to the left from his pursuit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Abner looked behind him and said, “Is that you, Asahel?”
He said, “Yes, it is.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner said to him, “Turn to your right hand or to your left and capture one of the young men for yourself and strip off his equipment for yourself.” But Asahel would not turn aside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abner warned him again, “Turn aside. Stop following me. Why should I strike you to the ground? How could I face Joab your brother?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Asahel refused to turn aside, so Abner struck him in the stomach with the pointed butt of his spear. The spear came out his back, and he fell down and died right there. Everyone stopped and just stood there when they came to the place where Asahel had fallen and died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Joab and Abishai keep pursuing Abner. The sun was going down when they came to the hill of Ammah in front of Giah, on the way to the wilderness of Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Benjaminites rallied together behind Abner, joined in one formation, and took their stand on the top of one hill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner called to Joab, “Will the sword continue to devour? Do you not know that it will be bitter when all this is over? How long will you delay telling the people to stop pursuing their brothers?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said, “As God lives, if you had not spoken, surely it would have been morning before the people would have given up pursuing their brothers.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab blew the ram’s horn, and all the people stopped pursuing Israel. They did not continue to fight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner and his men traveled through the Arabah all that night. They crossed the Jordan, marched through the entire region of Bithron, and came to Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab returned from pursuing Abner and gathered together all his troops. Besides Asahel, nineteen of David’s men were missing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The followers of David had struck dead three hundred sixty of Abner’s men from the tribe of Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The men of Judah picked up Asahel and buried him in the tomb of his father at Bethlehem.
Joab and his men marched all night and arrived at Hebron as it was becoming light.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The war between the house of Saul and the house of David lasted a long time. David kept getting stronger, and the house of Saul kept getting weaker.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sons were born to David at Hebron. His firstborn was Amnon, who was born to Ahinoam from Jezre’el.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His second was Kileab, who was born to Abigail, the widow of Nabal from Carmel. The third was Absalom, who was the son of Ma’akah, the daughter of Talmai king of Geshur.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fourth was Adonijah, the son of Haggith. The fifth was Shephatiah, the son of Abital.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sixth, Ithream, was born to David’s wife Eglah. These were born to David in Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While the war was going on between the house of Saul and the house of David, Abner kept gaining power within the house of Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul had a concubine named Rizpah daughter of Aiah. Ishbosheth said to Abner, “Why have you gone to the concubine of my father?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner became very angry because of the words of Ishbosheth and said, “Am I a dog’s head that belongs to Judah? To this day I have acted with loyalty toward the house of your father Saul, to his relatives, and to his friends. In addition, I have not handed you over to David, but today you make accusations against me concerning this woman!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May God punish me severely and double it, if I do not do for David what the Lord has sworn about him
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: by transferring the kingdom from the house of Saul and establishing the throne of David over both Israel and Judah, from Dan to Beersheba.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishbosheth was not able to say anything to Abner anymore because he was afraid of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner sent messengers on his behalf to David. They said, “Whose land is it? Make a covenant with me. Look, my hand is with you to turn the allegiance of all Israel to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said, “Good. I will make a covenant with you, but I require one thing from you. You will not see my face unless you bring to me Michal, the daughter of Saul, when you come.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David sent messengers to Ishbosheth, Saul’s son. They delivered this demand: “Give me my wife Michal, whom I obtained as my wife with a hundred foreskins of the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishbosheth sent and took her away from her husband, Paltiel son of Laish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Her husband accompanied her to Bahurim, weeping all the way, but Abner told him, “Go back,” so he went home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner also delivered the following message to the elders of Israel: “Day after day you have been seeking to have David as king over you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now do it, because the Lord said to David, ‘By the hand of my servant David I will rescue my people Israel from the hand of the Philistines and from the hand of all their enemies.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner also spoke to the tribe of Benjamin. Then he spoke to David in Hebron about everything that Israel and all the house of Benjamin had approved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner and twenty men along with him came to David at Hebron, and David held a feast for Abner and his men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner said to David, “I will go and gather all Israel to my lord the king. They will make a covenant with you. You will rule over all that your heart desires.” David sent Abner away in peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just then the soldiers of David and Joab came back from a raid. They brought a large amount of plunder with them. Abner was no longer with David in Hebron, because David had sent him away in peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joab and all the army with him arrived, Joab was informed that Abner son of Ner had come to the king and that David had sent him away in peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab went to the king and said, “What have you done? Abner came to you. Why have you sent him away? You let him get away!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You know that Abner son of Ner came to deceive you and to learn about your comings and goings and everything that you are doing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab left David and sent messengers after Abner. They brought him back from the cistern at Sirah without David’s knowledge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abner returned to Hebron, and Joab took him aside into the gatehouse to speak with him. There he stabbed him in the stomach. So Abner was killed because of the blood of Joab’s brother Asahel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterward David heard about it and said, “I and my kingdom are guiltless before the Lord forever concerning the blood of Abner son of Ner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May his blood splash down on the head of Joab and on the entire house of his father. May the house of Joab never lack a man who has an oozing sore, who is a leper, who holds a spindle, who falls by the sword, or who has no bread.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab and his brother Abishai killed Abner because he had caused the death of their brother Asahel during the battle at Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Joab and to all the people who were with him, “Tear your clothing. Put on sackcloth and mourn for Abner.” King David walked behind the stretcher that was carrying his body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They buried Abner at Hebron, and the king wept loudly at the grave of Abner. All the people also wept.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king lamented over Abner, “Should Abner have died as a fool dies?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your hands were not tied up, and your feet were not bound with iron shackles. You have fallen as one falls before the wicked.” All the people continued to weep over him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people came to try to persuade David to eat on that day, but David swore, “May God punish me severely and double it, if I taste bread or anything else before the sun goes down.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people took notice and approved of this, as they approved of everything that the king did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people, all Israel, knew on that day that it was not the king’s idea to kill Abner son of Ner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to his servants, “Do you not know that a great commander has fallen this day in Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Today I am weak, even though I am the anointed king. These men, the sons of Zeruiah, are too hard for me. I pray that the Lord will pay back the evildoer in proportion to his wickedness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul’s son heard that Abner had died at Hebron, he lost his courage, and all Israel panicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s son had two men who were commanders of raiding bands. One was named Ba’anah; the second was Rekab. They were Benjaminites, sons of Rimmon from Be’eroth. (Be’eroth is considered part of Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Be’erothites fled to Gittaim. They have lived there as aliens until the present time.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan, the son of Saul, had a son with crippled feet. This son had been five years old when the report had come from Jezre’el about Saul and Jonathan. His caregiver picked him up and fled. While she was hurrying to escape, he fell and became crippled. His name was Mephibosheth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ba’anah and Rekab, the sons of Rimmon from Be’eroth, went out during the heat of the day and came to the house of Ishbosheth while he was lying down for his midday rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ⎣The doorkeeper of the house had been cleaning wheat, but she had grown drowsy and fallen asleep. So Rekab and his brother Ba’anah slipped in.⎦ They came into the inner part of the house as if they were coming to get wheat. They stabbed Ishbosheth in the stomach. Then Rekab and his brother Ba’anah escaped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They had gone into the house while Ishbosheth was lying on his bed in the room where he rested. They struck him, killed him, and cut off his head. Taking his head with them, they traveled on the Arabah Road all night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought the head of Ishbosheth to David at Hebron, and they said to the king, “Look! Here is the head of Ishbosheth, the son of Saul, your enemy who sought your life. This day the Lord has given my lord the king vengeance on Saul and his offspring.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David answered Rekab and his brother Ba’anah, the sons of Rimmon from Be’eroth, “As the Lord lives, who has redeemed my life from every evil,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the man who told me, ‘Look! Saul is dead,’ thought that he was bringing good news, but I seized him and killed him at Ziklag. That is what I gave him for his ‘good news.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now that wicked men have killed a righteous man in his own house on his own bed, will I not require his blood from your hand! I will wipe you off the face of the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David gave the orders to his young men, and they killed them, cut off their hands and their feet, and hanged them beside the pool at Hebron. They took the head of Ishbosheth and buried it in the tomb of Abner in Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the tribes of Israel came to David at Hebron. They said, “Look, we are your flesh and blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Day after day, even when Saul was king, you were the one leading Israel out to battle and back again. And you are the one to whom the Lord said, ‘You will shepherd my people Israel. You will become leader over Israel.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the elders of Israel came to the king at Hebron, and King David made a covenant with them at Hebron in the presence of the Lord. They anointed David king over Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was thirty years old when he became king, and he ruled as king for forty years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was king over Judah at Hebron for seven years and six months. For thirty-three years he was king over all Israel and Judah at Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and his men went to Jerusalem against the Jebusites, who were living in the land. The Jebusites said to David, “You will not get in here, because you could be kept out even by the blind and lame, who say, ‘David will not come in here.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, David captured the stronghold of Zion, which became the City of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said on that day, “Anyone who attacks the Jebusites must go up through the water shaft to get at those lame and blind enemies of David.” Therefore the saying came about, “The blind and the lame will not come into the house.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David lived in the stronghold and called it the City of David. David built up all sides of the stronghold from the Millo inward.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David kept getting greater and greater, because the Lord, the God of Armies, was with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram king of Tyre sent representatives to David with cedar logs, carpenters, and stonemasons, and they built a palace for David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David knew that the Lord had established him as king over Israel and had lifted up his kingdom for the sake of his people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David took more concubines and wives from Jerusalem after he had come from Hebron, and more sons and daughters were born to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the names of those born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ibhar, Elishua, Nepheg, Japhia,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines heard that David had been anointed king over Israel. So all the Philistines went up to search for David. David, however, heard about it and went down to the stronghold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines came and spread out in the Valley of Rephaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David asked the Lord, “Shall I go up against the Philistines? Will you give them into my hand?”
The Lord said to David, “Go up, because I will certainly deliver the Philistines into your hand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David went to Baal Perazim and defeated them there. He said, “The Lord has broken through my enemies before me like a wall of water.” That is why he named that place Baal Perazim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines abandoned their idols there, and David and his men carried them away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines came up again and spread out in the Valley of Rephaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David inquired of the Lord, who said, “Do not go directly at them. Go around to their rear. Come upon them opposite the balsam trees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the balsam trees, then get ready, because then the Lord has gone out in front of you to strike the army of the Philistines.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David did as the Lord commanded him. He struck the Philistines from Gibeon all the way to Gezer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David once again gathered all of the thirty thousand specially chosen men of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David and all the people who were with him set out and went to Baale Judah to bring up the Ark of God, who is called by the name “The Lord of Armies, who sits above the cherubim.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They transported the Ark of God on a new cart. They brought it out from Abinadab’s house, which was on the hill. Uzzah and Ahio, the sons of Abinadab, were guiding the new cart
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ⎣⎦ with the Ark of God on it. Ahio was walking in front of the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and all the house of Israel were celebrating before the Lord with all kinds of instruments, castanets, lyres, harps, hand drums, rattles, and cymbals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they came to the threshing floor of Nakon, Uzzah reached out for the Ark of God and grabbed it because the oxen stumbled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The anger of the Lord burned against Uzzah, and God struck him there for his irreverence. So he died there beside the Ark of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was angry because the Lord had burst out so violently against Uzzah, and he called that place Perez Uzzah, as it is called to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was afraid of the Lord on that day. He said, “How can the Ark of the Lord come to me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David was not willing to move the Ark of the Lord to himself in the City of David.
So David diverted the ark to the house of Obed Edom the Gittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ark of the Lord remained at the house of Obed Edom the Gittite for three months, and the Lord blessed Obed Edom and his whole household.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David was told, “Because of the Ark of God, the Lord has blessed the house of Obed Edom and all that belongs to him.”
With rejoicing, David went and brought up the Ark of God from the house of Obed Edom to the City of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When those carrying the Ark of the Lord had gone six paces, David sacrificed an ox and a fattened calf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David danced with all his might before the Lord. He was wearing a linen vest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and the entire house of Israel brought up the Ark of the Lord with shouting and with the sound of a ram’s horn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Ark of the Lord arrived at the City of David, Michal, the daughter of Saul, looked out the window and saw King David leaping and dancing before the Lord, and she despised him in her heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought the Ark of the Lord and set it in its place inside the tent that David had pitched for it, and David offered burnt offerings and fellowship offerings before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David finished presenting the burnt offerings and the fellowship offerings, he blessed the people in the name of the Lord of Armies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He distributed one loaf of bread, one cake of dates, and one cake of raisins to all the people, to the whole crowd from Israel, to men and women, to each and every person. Then all the people left. All of them went to their own houses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and David returned to bless his house.
Michal, the daughter of Saul, came out to meet David. She said, “How the king of Israel has brought honor to himself today by exposing himself in the sight of his female servants, just as a vulgar person exposes himself!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Michal, “I did this before the Lord, who chose me above your father and all his house, when he appointed me leader over the people of the Lord, over Israel. I will rejoice before the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I will make myself even more lowly than this. I will be humble in my own eyes, but among the servant girls you have spoken about, among them I will be honored.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Michal, the daughter of Saul, had no child to the day of her death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened that when the king was living in his palace, and when the Lord had given him rest from his enemies all around,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the king said to Nathan the prophet, “Look, I live in a house of cedar, but the Ark of God sits under tent curtains.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nathan said to the king, “Go and do everything that is in your heart, because the Lord is with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But that night the word of the Lord came to Nathan. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Go and tell my servant David all these things.”
This is what the Lord says. Are you the one to build a house for me to live in?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have not lived in a house from the day I brought the people of Israel up from Egypt until today. I have been moving around in the Tent and the Dwelling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have traveled everywhere with all the people of Israel. Did I ever speak a word to any of the judges of Israel, whom I commanded to shepherd my people, or ask them, “Why have you not built a house of cedar for me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are also to say the following to my servant David.
This is what the Lord of Armies says. I took you from the pasture, from following sheep, to be ruler over my people, over Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have been with you wherever you went. I have cut off all your enemies from before you. I will make your reputation great, like that of the great ones on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will set up a place for my people Israel, and I will plant them there. They will dwell there, and they will not be disturbed again. Violent men will not afflict them again as they did at the beginning
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and ever since the day I appointed judges over my people Israel. I will give you rest from all your enemies.
The Lord also declares to you that the Lord himself will make a house for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When your days are complete and you rest with your fathers, I will raise up after you your seed, who will come from your own body. I will establish his kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will build a house for my name, and I will establish the throne of his kingdom forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will be his father, and he will be my son. When he sins, I will discipline him with a rod used by men and with blows of the sons of men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My faithful mercy will not depart from him as I removed it from Saul, whom I removed to make room for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your house will stand firm, and your kingdom will endure forever before you. Your throne will be established forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nathan told David all the words that had been revealed in this vision.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then King David went and sat before the Lord and said:
Who am I, Lord God? And what is my house that you have brought me to this point?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet this was a small thing in your eyes, Lord God. You have also spoken about the house of your servant for a long time into the future. Is this the law for the man, Lord God?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What more can David say to you? You know your servant, Lord God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because of your word and according to the plan of your heart, you have carried out this great thing in order to make your servant aware of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, you are great, Lord God, because there is none like you. There is no God except you, in keeping with everything we have heard with our ears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who is like your people Israel, the one people on earth whom God went out to redeem for himself, to make them his people and to make a name for himself? You yourself did great and awe-inspiring things for your land in the presence of your people, whom you redeemed for yourself from Egypt, in the presence of the nations and their gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You established your people Israel for yourself to be your people forever. You, Lord, became their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, Lord God, confirm forever the word that you have spoken concerning your servant and concerning his house, and do as you have spoken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your name will be great forever. People will say, “The Lord of Armies is God over Israel.” The house of your servant David will be established before you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You, Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, have whispered into the ear of your servant, saying, “I will build a house for you.” Therefore, your servant has found the heart to pray to you this prayer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, Lord God, you are God. Your words are truth. You have promised this good thing to your servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, therefore, please bless the house of your servant, so that it will endure forever in your presence. For you, Lord God, have spoken. With your blessing the house of your servant will be blessed forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, David defeated the Philistines and subdued them. David took Metheg Ha’ammah from the control of the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He defeated Moab and measured the men with a length of rope after making them lie down on the ground. He measured two lengths to be put to death and one full length to live. The Moabites became subject to David and brought tribute.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David also defeated Hadadezer son of Rehob, king of Zobah, when he went to restore his control at the river Euphrates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David captured seventeen hundred charioteers and twenty thousand foot soldiers from him. David hamstrung all the chariot horses, but he left enough horses for a hundred chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Arameans from Damascus came to help Hadadezer king of Zobah, but David killed twenty-two thousand men in Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then David put garrisons in Damascus in the land of Aram, and the Arameans became subject to David and brought tribute.
The Lord gave victory to David everywhere he went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David took the gold shields that belonged to the officials of Hadadezer and brought them to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From Betah and Berothai, cities of Hadadezer, King David took large amounts of bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Toi king of Hamath heard that David had defeated the entire army of Hadadezer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Toi sent his son Joram to King David to petition him for peace and to bless him because he had fought against Hadadezer and defeated him, because Toi had been at war with Hadadezer. In his hand he brought items made of silver and items of gold and items of bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David dedicated these things to the Lord along with the silver and gold that he had dedicated from all the nations he had subdued:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from Aram, Moab, the Ammonites, the Philistines, from Amalek, and from the spoils of Hadadezer son of Rehob, king of Zobah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David made a name for himself when he returned from striking eighteen thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He put garrisons in Edom, in all of it, and all the Edomites became subject to David.
The Lord gave victory to David wherever he went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was king over all Israel, and he treated all his people with justice and fairness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab son of Zeruiah was over the army. Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was the record keeper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zadok son of Ahitub and Ahimelek son of Abiathar were priests. Seraiah was the secretary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was in charge of the Kerethites and the Pelethites. The sons of David were government ministers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said, “Is there anyone still left from the house of Saul, to whom I may show kindness for the sake of Jonathan?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There was a servant of Saul’s house named Ziba, so they summoned him to come to David.
The king said to him, “Are you Ziba?” He said, “I am.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king said, “Isn’t there still a man left who belongs to the house of Saul, to whom I may show the kindness of God?”
Ziba said to the king, “There is still a son of Jonathan. He has crippled feet.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king said to him, “Where is he?”
Ziba said to the king, “He is in the house of Makir son of Ammiel in Lo Debar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King David sent and brought him from the house of Makir son of Ammiel from Lo Debar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Mephibosheth, the son of Saul’s son Jonathan, came to David, he bowed facedown to the ground.
David said, “Mephibosheth?” He said, “I am.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “Do not be afraid. I will certainly show kindness to you because of Jonathan, your father. I will return to you all the land of your grandfather Saul, and you will always eat bread at my table.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He bowed down and said, “What is your servant that you have paid attention to a dead dog like me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king called Ziba, Saul’s servant, and said to him, “Everything that belonged to Saul and to his entire house I am giving to your master’s son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are to work the soil for him, you and your sons and your servants. You are to bring in the crops, so your master’s son will have food to eat. Mephibosheth, your master’s son, will always eat bread at my table.”
(Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ziba said to the king, “Everything that my lord the king commands his servant, your servant will do.”
So Mephibosheth began eating at the king’s table like one of the king’s sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth had a young son named Mica. Everyone living in Ziba’s house became servants of Mephibosheth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Mephibosheth took up residence in Jerusalem because he was always to eat at the table of the king. He was crippled in both his feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, the king of the Ammonites died, and his son Hanun became king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said, “I will show kindness to Hanun son of Nahash, just as his father showed kindness to me.” So David sent his officials to express condolences to Hanun concerning his father. David’s officials arrived in the land of the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the officials of the Ammonites said to Hanun their master, “Do you really think David was honoring your father when he sent messengers to express his sympathy to you? No, David sent his officials to you in order to gather information about the city and to spy on it, in order to overthrow it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hanun seized the officials of David, shaved off half of each one’s beard, cut off their clothing up to their buttocks, and sent them away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was told about this, and he sent messengers to meet them because the men were deeply humiliated. The king said, “Stay in Jericho until your beards have grown. Then return.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ammonites saw that they had become a digusting stench to David, so they sent and hired twenty thousand foot soldiers from Aram Beth Rehob and Aram Zobah, one thousand men from the king of Ma’akah, and twelve thousand men from Tob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David heard about it, he deployed Joab and the entire army, the strong warriors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ammonites went out and lined up in battle formation in front of the entrance to the city gate. Aram Zobah and Aram Rehob, as well as the men of Tob and Ma’akah, were lined up by themselves in the open country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab saw that the battle lines were drawn up against him both in front of him and behind him, so he chose some of the best troops of Israel and lined them up to confront the Arameans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the men he placed under the command of his brother Abishai and lined them up to face the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “If Aram is too strong for me, then you are to rescue me. If the Ammonites are too strong for you, I will come to rescue you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be strong. We must show ourselves to be strong for our people and for the cities of our God. The Lord will do what is good in his eyes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab and all the people with him advanced to join battle against the Arameans, and the Arameans fled from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Ammonites saw that Aram had fled, they also fled from Abishai and entered the city. Then Joab returned from fighting against the Ammonites and came back to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Arameans saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they regrouped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hadadezer sent for Arameans from beyond the Euphrates. They came to Helam with Shobak, who was the commander of the army of Hadadezer, at their head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David was informed, he gathered all Israel, crossed the Jordan, and came to Helam. The Arameans lined up to confront David and fought against him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Arameans fled from Israel. David killed seven hundred Aramean charioteers and forty thousand foot soldiers. Shobak, the commander of their army, was wounded, and he died there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the kings who were the subjects of Hadadezer saw that they had been defeated by Israel, so they made peace with Israel and became subject to them. Then the Arameans were afraid to try to rescue the Ammonites anymore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Springtime arrived, the time when kings go out to war. David sent Joab out with his officers and with all Israel. They ravaged the Ammonites and besieged Rabbah. But David stayed in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One evening David had gotten up from his couch and was walking around on the roof of the palace. From the roof he saw a woman bathing. The woman was very good looking.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David sent to inquire about the woman, and he was told, “Isn’t this Bathsheba daughter of Eliam, the wife of Uriah the Hittite?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David sent messengers to bring her. She came to him, and he lay down with her. (She had been purifying herself from her ceremonial uncleanness.) She then returned to her house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman became pregnant, so she sent a message and told David, “I am pregnant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David sent a message to Joab, “Send Uriah the Hittite to me.” So Joab sent Uriah to David,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and Uriah came to him.
David asked how Joab and the troops were doing, and how the war effort was going.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then David said to Uriah, “Go down to your house and wash your feet.”
When Uriah went out from the palace, the king sent a gift to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Uriah slept at the entrance to the palace with all the servants of his master. He did not go down to his own house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was informed, “Uriah has not gone down to his house.” So David said to Uriah, “Haven’t you come a long distance? Why didn’t you go down to your house?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uriah said to David, “The ark and Israel and Judah are living in shelters, and my master Joab and the servants of my master are camped on the bare ground in the open countryside. Should I go to my house to eat and to drink and to lie down with my wife? By your life, as surely as you live, I will not do such a thing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Uriah, “Stay here today also. Tomorrow I will send you back.” So Uriah remained in Jerusalem that day and the next.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David summoned him, and Uriah ate as his guest, and David got him drunk. But in the evening he went and slept on his mat where the servants of his master were. He did not go to his own house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning David wrote a letter to Joab, and he sent it in the hands of Uriah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the letter he wrote, “Station Uriah opposite the fiercest fighting. Then withdraw from behind him so that he will be struck down and die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when Joab was besieging the city, he assigned Uriah to a place where he knew that the enemy’s strongest warriors were.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of the city came out and fought against Joab, and some of the troops of David fell. Uriah the Hittite also died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab sent a message to inform David about all the events of the war.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He instructed the messenger, “As you are finishing reporting all the events of the war to the king,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: if the king becomes angry and says to you, ‘Why did you go so close to the city to fight? Didn’t you know that they would be shooting from on top of the wall?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who killed Abimelek son of Jerubbesheth? Didn’t a woman throw an upper millstone from the wall on him, so that he died at Thebez? Why did you go so close to the wall?’ Then you are to say, ‘Your servant Uriah the Hittite also died.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The messenger set out. He came and told David everything that Joab had sent him to say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The messenger said to David, “Their men gained an advantage over us and drove us back into the open country. But then we gained the upper hand and drove them back all the way to the entrance of the city gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The archers shot at your troops from the wall. Some of the servants of the king died. And your servant Uriah the Hittite also died.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David told the messenger, “Say this to Joab: ‘Do not take this too hard, because the sword devours people at random. Strengthen your attack against the city, and overthrow it.’ Encourage Joab.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wife of Uriah the Hittite heard that her husband was dead, so she mourned for her husband.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When her mourning was completed, David sent for her and brought her to his house, and she became his wife. She gave birth to a son for him. But what David had done was evil in the eyes of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the Lord sent Nathan to David. He came and told him this:
There were two men in a city. One was rich and one poor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rich man had a large number of flocks and herds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The poor man did not own anything except one little ewe lamb, which he had bought. He raised it so that it grew up together with him and his children. It ate from his food and drank from his cup. It slept in his arms. It was like a daughter to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When a traveler came to the rich man, the rich man was unwilling to take an animal from his flock or from his herd to prepare a meal for the traveler who had come to him. So he took the lamb from the poor man and prepared it for the man who had come to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David’s anger flared up against that man. He said to Nathan, “As the Lord lives, the man who has done this is as good as dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In place of that lamb, he will restore four lambs, because he did this and had no pity.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Nathan told David, “You are the man. This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says.”
I anointed you king over Israel. I rescued you from the hand of Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I gave the house of your master to you, and I gave the wives of your master into your embrace. I gave you the house of Israel and the house of Judah. If this was too little, I would have added even more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why have you despised the word of the Lord by doing evil in his eyes? You have struck down Uriah the Hittite with the sword. You have taken his wife as your own wife. You have killed him with the sword of the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now the sword will not depart from your house forever, because you have despised me and have taken the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be your wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord says. Look! I am raising up disaster against you from your own house. Right in front of your eyes I will take your wives and give them to your neighbor, and he will lie down with your wives in the sight of the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because you acted in secret, I will do this in front of all Israel in broad daylight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David said to Nathan, “I have sinned against the Lord.”
Nathan said to David, “The Lord himself has put away your sin. You will not die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, because by this deed you have treated the Lord with utter contempt, the child that is born to you shall surely die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Nathan went to his house.
The Lord struck the child that Uriah’s wife had borne for David, and the child became sick.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David sought the Lord’s mercy for the child. David fasted and spent the night lying on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The elders of his household stood beside him to pick him up off the ground, but he was not willing, and he would not eat food with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the seventh day the child died. The servants of David were afraid to tell him that the child was dead, because they said, “Look! When the child was living, we spoke to David, but he did not listen to what we said. How will we speak to him now when the child is dead? He might do something harmful.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David saw that his servants were whispering together, he understood that the child was dead. So David said to his servants, “Is the child dead?” They said, “Yes, he is dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David got up from the ground, washed, put on lotion, and changed his clothes. He went to the House of the Lord and worshipped. He then went back to his house and asked for food. So they prepared a meal for him, and he ate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His servants said to him, “What are you doing? While the child was alive, you fasted and wept. But when the child died, you got up and ate food.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “While the child was alive, I fasted and wept because I said, ‘Who knows? Will the Lord be gracious to me and let my child live?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now he has died. Why should I fast? Am I able to return him to life again? I will go to him, but he will not return to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David comforted Bathsheba, his wife. He went to her and lay down with her. She gave birth to a son. David called him Solomon. The Lord loved him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the Lord sent a message by the hand of Nathan the prophet that he should be called Jedidiah because of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab fought against Rabbah of the Ammonites and captured the royal city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent messengers to David and said, “I have fought against Rabbah. I have also captured the city’s water supply.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now gather the rest of the troops, set up camp against the city, and take it. If you do not, I might take the city, and it will be named after me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David gathered all the troops and went to Rabbah. He fought against it and took it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He removed the gold crown of their king from his head. It weighed seventy-five pounds, and it had a precious stone. It was placed on the head of David.
He brought out large quantities of plunder from the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also brought the people out from it and made them work with saws, with iron picks and axes, and at brickmaking. He did the same to all the cities of the Ammonites. Then David and all the troops returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David’s son Absalom had a beautiful sister named Tamar. Some time after this, David’s son Amnon fell in love with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amnon was so worked up that he made himself sick because of his sister Tamar. She was a virgin, and it seemed impossible for Amnon to do anything with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amnon had a friend named Jonadab, who was a son of David’s brother Shimeah. Jonadab was a very clever man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Jonadab said to Amnon, “Why do you, the king’s son, look so tired every morning? Won’t you tell me?”
Amnon said to him, “I am in love with Tamar, the sister of my brother Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonadab said to him, “Lie down on your bed and pretend to be sick. Your father will come to see you. Then you are to say to him, ‘Please! Have my sister Tamar come and give me some food to eat. Have her prepare the food in my presence so that I can watch and eat it from her hand.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Amnon went to bed and pretended to be sick, and the king came to see him. Amnon said to the king, “Please! Have my sister Tamar come and make special flatbread while I am watching. She should make two of them and let me eat them from her hand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David sent a message to Tamar’s house: “Please, go to the house of your brother Amnon and make food for him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tamar went to the house of her brother Amnon, where he was lying down. She took dough, kneaded it, made the flatbread as he was watching, and baked the loaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She took the pan and placed it before him, but he refused to eat.
Amnon said, “Send everyone away from me.” So everyone left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Amnon said to Tamar, “Bring the food into the bedroom and let me eat from your hand.”
Tamar took the flatbread that she had made and brought it into the room to Amnon her brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She brought it to him so he could eat.
He grabbed her and said to her, “Come, lie down with me, my sister.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said to him, “No, my brother. Do not force me, for such a thing is not done in Israel. Do not do such a foolish thing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I—how will I get rid of my shame? And you will be like one of the fools in Israel. Now, please speak to the king, for he will not withhold me from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he would not listen to her. He was stronger than she was, and he forced her to lie down with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Amnon’s hatred for her was even more intense than the love he had felt for her. Amnon said to her, “Get up. Get out.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She said to him, “There is no excuse for that. To send me away is a greater wrong than what you already did to me.”
But he was not willing to listen to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He called the young man who was his servant and said, “Send this woman outside, away from me, and bolt the door behind her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She was wearing a special long robe that covered her arms and legs. The virgin daughters of the king wore such robes. His servant put her outside and bolted the door after her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tamar put ashes on her head and ripped the robe that she was wearing. She placed her hand on her head, and she went away, weeping loudly as she walked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Her brother Absalom said to her, “Has Amnon your brother been with you? Now my sister, do not say anything. He is your brother. Do not take this matter to heart.”
So Tamar, a devastated woman, stayed in the house of her brother Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David heard about all these things, and he was very angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom did not speak with Amnon at all, neither anything bad nor anything good. Absalom hated Amnon because he had raped Tamar, his sister.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two years passed. Absalom’s sheepshearers were at Baal Hazor, which is near Ephraim. Absalom invited all the king’s sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom also came to the king and said, “Look! The sheepshearers are now at work for your servant. Will the king and his servants join your servant, please?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king said to Absalom, “No, my son. Not all of us will go. We do not want to be a burden to you.”
Absalom pressured him, but David was not willing to go, though he did give Absalom a blessing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Absalom said, “If not, can Amnon my brother join us, please?” The king said to him, “Why should he go with you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Absalom kept pressuring him, so David sent Amnon and all the sons of the king with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom commanded his servants, “Pay attention to me, and when Amnon is feeling good because of the wine, I will say to you, ‘Strike Amnon.’ Then you are to kill him. Do not be afraid. I am the one who has given you the order. Be strong. Be brave.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom’s servants did to Amnon exactly what Absalom had commanded. Then all the sons of the king got up. Each of them got on his mule and fled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were on the way, news reached David: “Absalom has killed all the king’s sons. There is not one of them left.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king got up, ripped his clothing, and lay down on the ground. All his servants who were standing nearby also ripped their clothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonadab, the son of David’s brother Shimeah, responded, “My lord should not say they have killed all the young men who are sons of the king, for only Amnon is dead. This is what Absalom has been planning from the day Amnon raped Tamar, his sister.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now my lord the king should pay no attention to the report that says, ‘All the king’s sons are dead,’ because only Amnon is dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Absalom fled.
The young man who was serving as the watchman looked up and saw many people coming down the road west of him, along the side of the mountain. ⎣The watchman came and reported to the king, “I see men on the Horonaim road, along the side of the mountain.”⎦
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonadab said to the king, “Look. The king’s sons have come. It is just as your servant said.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he was finished speaking, the king’s sons arrived. They raised their voices and wept loudly. The king and all his servants also wept very bitterly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom fled. He went to Talmai son of Ammihud, the king of Geshur. King David mourned every day because of his son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom fled and went to Geshur. He stayed there for three years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David longed to reach out to Absalom, because he was no longer mourning for his deceased son Amnon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab son of Zeruiah knew that the heart of the king was attached to Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab sent to Tekoa and brought a wise woman from there. He said to her, “Please act like a mourner and wear mourning clothes. Do not anoint yourself with lotion. Make it look as if you are a woman who has been mourning for the dead for a long time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go to the king and tell him whatever I tell you to say.” Then Joab put the words in her mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman from Tekoa spoke to the king. She fell down with her face to the ground. She bowed down and said, “Help me, O King.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king said to her, “What is wrong?”
She said, “It’s terrible. I am a widow. My husband is dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servant had two sons. The two of them had a fight out in the field, and there was no one there to separate them. The one struck the other and killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the entire family has risen up against your servant. They are saying, ‘Turn over the one who struck down his brother, so we can put him to death because of the life of his brother whom he killed. In this way we will destroy the heir also.’ They will put out the fire of the one burning coal that is left for me. My husband will not have a name or anything left on the face of the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to the woman, “Go to your house. I will issue orders on your behalf.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman from Tekoa said to the king, “On me, my lord the king—let the guilt be on me and on the house of my father. The king and his throne will be guiltless.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “Bring to me anyone who speaks against you about this, and he will not contact you again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She said, “Please, the king should remember the Lord your God and stop the avenger of blood from multiplying the killing, so that they do not destroy my son.”
David said, “As the Lord lives, not one hair of your son will fall to the ground.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The woman said, “Please allow your servant to speak a word to my lord the king.”
He said, “Speak up.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman said, “Why have you planned something like this against the people of God? By his own words the king convicts himself for not returning his own banished one.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We will certainly die. We are like water spilled onto the ground that cannot be gathered up again. But God does not take life. He devises means to restore to himself the one who has been banished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I have come to say this to my lord the king, because the people have made me afraid. Your servant said, ‘I will speak to the king. Perhaps the king will fulfill the request of his servant,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for the king will listen and deliver his servant from the hand of the man who is trying to destroy both me and my son, to remove us from our inheritance from God.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servant said, ‘Please let the word of my lord the king give me rest, because he is like the angel of God—that is what my lord the king is like. He is able to distinguish good and evil.’ The Lord your God will be with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king answered the woman, “Please, do not withhold the answer to what I am about to ask you.”
The woman said, “My lord the king, please speak.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king said, “Is the hand of Joab with you in all this?”
The woman answered, “As your soul lives, my lord the king, nothing veers off to the right or to the left from everything my lord the king has said, for your servant Joab is the one who gave me orders. He also put all these words into the mouth of your servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servant Joab did this in order to change the way things were going. My lord has wisdom, like the wisdom of the Angel of God. He knows everything that goes on in the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Joab, “All right! I will do this. Go and bring back the young man Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab fell down with his face to the ground. He bowed down and blessed the king and said, “Today your servant has become aware that I have found favor in your sight, my lord the king, because the king has carried out the request of his servant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab got up and went to Geshur and brought Absalom back to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king said, “He must go to his own house. He is not to see me face-to-face.” So Absalom went to his own house, and he did not see the face of the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was not a man in all Israel as handsome as Absalom and so greatly praised. From the sole of his foot to the top of his head there was not a blemish on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he shaved the hair on his head (periodically he cut it off because it became too heavy for him), the hair weighed five pounds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three sons and one daughter were born to Absalom. The daughter’s name was Tamar. She was an attractive woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom lived in Jerusalem for two years, but he did not see the king face-to-face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom sent to Joab in order to ask him to go to the king on his behalf, but Joab was not willing to come to him. Absalom sent again, a second time, but Joab was still not willing to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Absalom said to his servants, “See that field of Joab next to mine, where he has barley. Go and set it on fire.” So Absalom’s servants set the field on fire. ⎣Joab’s servants came to him with their clothing torn and said to him, “The servants of Absalom have set your field on fire.”⎦
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab got up and went to Absalom’s house. He said to him, “Why have your servants set my field on fire?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom said to Joab, “I sent this message to you: Come here. I want to send you to speak to the king and to say for me, ‘Why did I come from Geshur? It would be better for me to still be there.’ Now I want to see the king face-to-face. If I am guilty of anything, let him put me to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Joab went to the king and gave him the message.
Then the king summoned Absalom, and he came to the king. He bowed down to the king with his face to the ground, and the king kissed Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Absalom acquired for himself a chariot, horses, and fifty men to run in front of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom would get up early and stand beside the road by the gatehouse. Absalom would call out to every man who had a legal issue to bring before the king for judgment, and he would say, “What city are you from?” The person would say, “Your servant is from such-and-such of the tribes of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom would say to him, “Your claims are good and valid, but there is no one from the king to listen to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom would say, “I wish someone would make me a judge in the land. Then everyone who has a legal issue or needs a judgment could come to me, and I would give him justice.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever someone approached to bow down to him, he would reach out, take hold of him, and kiss him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom acted this way to everyone of Israel who came to the king for judgment. In this way Absalom stole the hearts of the men of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After four years Absalom said to the king, “Please let me go to Hebron and fulfill my vow, which I have made to the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because when I was at Geshur in Aram, your servant vowed, ‘If the Lord will really return me to Jerusalem, I will serve the Lord.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to him, “Go in peace.” So he set out and went to Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Absalom sent agents throughout all the tribes of Israel, saying, “When you hear the sound of the ram’s horn, you are to say, ‘Absalom is king in Hebron.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two hundred men from Jerusalem who had been invited went along with Absalom. They went innocently, since they did not know what was going on.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While he was offering sacrifices, Absalom summoned David’s advisor, Ahithophel of Giloh, to come from Giloh, his hometown. The conspiracy gained strength as more and more people were going over to Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A messenger came to David and said, “The hearts of the men of Israel are following Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David said to all his servants who were with him at Jerusalem, “Get ready. We must flee, or we will not escape from Absalom. Hurry up and go, so that he does not come quickly, overtake us, bring down disaster on us, and strike the city with the edge of the sword.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The officials of the king said to him, “Here we are. We, your servants, will do everything our lord the king decides.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king set out with his entire household, but he left ten concubines to watch over the house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and all his people set out. They stopped at a house some distance away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All his troops were passing by in front of David. All the Kerethites, Pelethites, and Gittites—six hundred men from Gath who had come under his command—were passing by in front of the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Ittai from Gath, “Why are you going with us? Go back and stay with King Absalom, because you are a foreigner and an exile from your home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You arrived just yesterday. Today should I cause you to wander with us, when I myself do not have a plan as to where I am going? Go back and take your fellow soldiers with you. May the Lord’s mercy and faithfulness be with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ittai answered the king, “As the Lord lives and as my lord the king lives, wherever my lord the king will be, whether it leads to death or life, there your servant will be.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Ittai, “Go ahead then. March on.” So Ittai from Gath and all his men and all the dependents who were with them marched by.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people of the land wept loudly as all the troops were marching by. The king crossed over the stream bed of the Kidron. All the people kept marching by in the direction of the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next came Zadok and all the Levites with him, who were carrying the Ark of the Covenant of God. They set down the Ark of God, and Abiathar offered up sacrifices until all the people finished passing by, as they left the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Zadok, “Return the Ark of God to the city. If I find favor in the eyes of the Lord, he will bring me back and let me see it in its proper dwelling place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if he says, ‘I have no pleasure in you,’ look, here I am. Let him do to me whatever is good in his eyes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Zadok the priest, “Aren’t you a seer? Go back to the city in peace. You two priests, take your sons with you—your son Ahima’az and Abiathar’s son Jonathan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Listen, I will be waiting at the fords in the wilderness until word comes from you to inform me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Zadok and Abiathar carried the Ark of God back to Jerusalem, and they remained there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David went up along the ascent to the top of the Mount of Olives. As he walked along with his head covered, he was weeping, and he was walking barefoot. All the people who were with him also covered their heads. As they went up, they were weeping as they walked along.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David had been told, “Ahithophel is among the conspirators with Absalom.” So David said, “Please, Lord, make the advice of Ahithophel foolish.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David arrived at the summit, where he worshipped God.
Hushai the Arkite was there to meet him. His robe was torn, and he had dirt on his head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to him, “If you cross over with me, you will become a burden to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you return to the city and you say to Absalom, ‘Let me be your servant, O King. In the past I was a servant of your father. Now I will be your servant,’ then you can defeat the advice of Ahithophel for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Are not Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, with you there? Tell every word that you hear in the house of the king to Zadok and Abiathar, the priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their two sons, Zadok’s son Ahima’az and Abiathar’s son Jonathan, are there with them. Through those two, the three of you will be able to send me every word that you hear.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hushai, the friend and advisor of David, went to the city, just as Absalom also was entering into Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David moved a little beyond the summit. There Ziba, the servant of Mephibosheth, met him with a string of saddled donkeys. On them there were two hundred loaves of bread, one hundred cakes of raisins, one hundred cakes of summer fruit, and a container of wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king said to Ziba, “Why do you have these?”
Ziba said, “The donkeys are for the household of the king to ride on. The bread and fruit are for the young men to eat. The wine is to provide something to drink for those who become exhausted in the wilderness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king said, “So where is the grandson of your master?”
Ziba said to the king, “Well, he is staying in Jerusalem because he said, ‘Today the house of Israel will return the kingdom of my grandfather to me.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king said to Ziba, “All right then. Everything that was Mephibosheth’s belongs to you.”
Ziba said, “I bow down before you. May I find favor in your sight, my lord the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David came to Bahurim. There he was confronted by a man from the family of the house of Saul. His name was Shimei son of Gera. He was rushing out and calling down curses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He threw stones at David and at all the servants of King David, as well as at all the people and all the warriors on David’s right and on his left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what Shimei said as he cursed: “Get out! Get out, you bloody, worthless man!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord has avenged upon you all the blood of the house of Saul, whom you replaced as king. The Lord has given the kingdom into the hand of your son Absalom. Just look at you now, sunk in disaster, because you are a bloody man.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abishai son of Zeruiah said to the king, “Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Please let me go over and take off his head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “What do you and I have in common, you sons of Zeruiah? If he is cursing because the Lord has told him, ‘Curse David,’ then who can say, ‘Why have you done this?’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David said to Abishai and to all his followers, “Listen to me! My son, who came from my own body, is seeking my life. How much more now, this Benjaminite! Leave him alone. Let him curse. Perhaps the Lord has told him to do so.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Perhaps the Lord will look on my misery and will return something good to me in exchange for his cursing this day.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and his men kept traveling down the road, and Shimei kept following along, on the side of the hill opposite him, walking along, cursing, throwing stones, and flinging dirt at him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and all the people who were with him traveled until they became exhausted, and then they stopped in order to recover.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom and all the people, the men of Israel, arrived at Jerusalem. Ahithophel was with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hushai the Arkite, David’s confidant, came to Absalom, Hushai said to Absalom, “Long live the king! Long live the king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom said to Hushai, “Is this your loyalty for your friend? Why didn’t you go with your friend?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hushai said to Absalom, “No. The person who has been chosen by the Lord, by this people, and by all the men of Israel—this is the one with whom I will be and with whom I will remain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Besides, whom should I serve if not the king’s son? As I have served your father, so I will serve you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom said to Ahithophel, “Give us your advice. What should we do?”
verses.speaker: Narrator
