verses.text: Ahithophel said to Absalom, “Go to your father’s concubines, whom he has left to watch over the palace. Let all Israel hear that you have become disgusting to your father, so that the hands of all who are with you may be strengthened.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they pitched a tent on the roof for Absalom, and Absalom went to his father’s concubines in the sight of all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In those days the advice that Ahithophel gave was viewed as if it had come from God. All the advice of Ahithophel was viewed that way, both by David and also by Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahithophel said to Absalom, “Let me choose twelve thousand men. I will set out to pursue David tonight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will come upon him when he is tired and weak and cause him to panic. All the people with him will flee. Then I will strike down only the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will bring back the rest of the people to you. The life of the man whom you are seeking will gain the return of all of them. All the rest of the people will be safe.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahithophel’s plan seemed good to all the elders of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Absalom said, “Call Hushai the Arkite. We should also hear what he has to say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hushai came to Absalom, and Absalom said to him, “This is what Ahithophel has said. Shall we do it? If you disagree, speak up.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hushai said to Absalom, “This time the advice Ahithophel has given is not good.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hushai continued, “You know your father and his men. They are fierce warriors, like an enraged bear in the open country who has lost her cubs. Your father is a fighter. He will not spend the night with the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Certainly, by now he has hidden himself in one of the caves or in some other place. What if he attacks and some of our men fall first? Whoever hears about it will say, ‘There has been a slaughter among the followers of Absalom.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even the very brave, whose hearts are like the heart of a lion, will melt with fear, because all Israel knows that your father is a fierce warrior, and that those who are with him are brave men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So, I advise you to gather all Israel to you from Dan to Beersheba, as many as the sand beside the sea, and that you personally lead them into battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We should attack the king in whatever place he is found. We will come down on him like the dew that falls upon the ground. There will not even be one survivor from him and from all the men with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he withdraws into a city, all Israel should bring ropes to that city. We will drag it into the valley until there will not be even one pebble found there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Absalom and all the men of Israel said, “The advice of Hushai the Arkite is better than the advice of Ahithophel.”
The Lord had arranged to defeat the good advice of Ahithophel, so that the Lord could bring disaster upon Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Hushai told Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, “This is what Ahithophel advised Absalom and the elders of Israel. But this is what I have advised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now send a message quickly and tell David, ‘Do not stay tonight at the fords in the wilderness. Also, be sure to cross over the river, or the king and all the people who are with him will be swallowed up.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan and Ahima’az were to wait at En Rogel because they could not risk being seen going into the city. A female servant was to go out and inform them. Then they could go and tell King David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, a young man saw them and told Absalom. So the two of them quickly went to the house of a man at Bahurim. He had a well in his courtyard, and they climbed down into it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His wife took a cover, spread it over the mouth of the well, and scattered grain on it. Nobody knew that she did it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Absalom’s servants came to the woman at the house and said, “Where are Ahima’az and Jonathan?”
The woman said to them, “They have passed by toward the river.” Absalom’s servants pursued them but did not find them, so they returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they left, Ahima’az and Jonathan climbed out of the well. They went and reported to King David, and they said to him, “Get up and cross over the river quickly because this is what Ahithophel advised against you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David and all the people who were with him set out and crossed the Jordan, beginning at the first light of day and continuing until everyone had crossed over the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahithophel saw that his advice had not been followed, he saddled his donkey, set out, went to his house in his hometown, and set his household in order. Then he hanged himself. He died, and he was buried in the tomb of his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David went to Mahanaim, and Absalom crossed over the Jordan with all the men of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom had put Amasa in command of the army instead of Joab. (Amasa was the son of a man named Ithra, an Ishmaelite who had gone to Abigal, the daughter of Nahash, the sister of Zeruiah, the mother of Joab.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel and Absalom set up camp in the land of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David came to Mahanaim, Shobi son of Nahash from Rabbah of the Ammonites, Makir son of Ammiel from Lo Debar, and Barzillai the Gileadite from Rogelim
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: brought beds, basins, pottery, wheat, barley, flour, roasted grain, beans, lentils,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: honey, cheese curds, sheep, and cheese from cow’s milk for David and for the people with him to eat, because they said, “The people are hungry, tired, and thirsty in the wilderness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David organized the troops who were with him. He appointed leaders over units of a thousand and units of a hundred.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then David sent the troops out: one third under the command of Joab; one third under the command of Abishai, who was the son of Zeruiah and the brother of Joab; and one third under the command of Ittai from Gath.
The king said to the troops, “I myself will definitely also go with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the troops said, “You will not go, because if we flee, they will not target us. Even if half of us die, they will not target us, for there are ten thousand others like us. No. It is better now that you support us from the city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the king said to them, “Whatever seems best to you, I will do.”
The king stood beside the city gate. All the troops marched out by units of a hundred and a thousand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king gave orders to Joab, Abishai, and Ittai: “For my sake, act gently with the young man Absalom.” All the troops heard the king giving orders to the leaders concerning Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The troops went out into the countryside to confront Israel. The battle took place in the Forest of Ephraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Israel were defeated there by the followers of David. There was a great slaughter there on that day—twenty thousand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The battle was spread over the entire area. The forest devoured more people than the sword did on that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom encountered the forces of David. As Absalom was riding on his mule, the mule went under the thick branches of a large terebinth tree, and Absalom’s head caught in the terebinth. He was caught between heaven and earth, and the mule he was riding kept going.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A man noticed Absalom and told Joab, “Listen! I saw Absalom hanging in a terebinth tree!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said to the man who had told him, “What! You saw him! Why didn’t you strike him to the ground right there? Then I would have given you ten shekels of silver and a belt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the man said to Joab, “Even if I had one thousand shekels of silver weighed out into my hands, I would not reach my hand out against the king’s son. We heard the king command you, Abishai, and Ittai, ‘Watch out for the young man Absalom for me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If I had acted irresponsibly with my life—and nothing is hidden from the king—you would not have stood by me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said, “I will not waste time with you like this.” He took three small spears in his hand, and he hurled them into Absalom’s heart while he was still alive in the middle of the terebinth tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ten young men, the ones carrying Joab’s armor and weapons, surrounded Absalom and struck and killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab blew the ram’s horn, and the people turned back from pursuing Israel, because Joab restrained them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They took Absalom and threw him into a large pit in the forest. They raised a huge pile of stones over him.
All Israel fled, everyone to his own tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During his lifetime Absalom had set up a monument for himself in the Valley of the King, because he said, “I do not have a son to keep my name alive in people’s memory.” He named the monument after himself, and it is called Absalom’s Monument to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahima’az son of Zadok said, “Let me run and carry the good news to the king that the Lord has delivered him from the power of his enemies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Joab said to him, “You are not the man to carry the news today. You may carry the news some other day, but today you should not carry the news, because the king’s son is dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Joab then told a Cushite, “Go, tell the king what you saw.”
The Cushite bowed down to Joab and then set out running.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But Ahima’az son of Zadok said to Joab again, “No matter what, I really want to run behind the Cushite.”
Joab said, “Why do you want to do this? My son, there is no good news that will bring you any gain for running.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Ahima’az said, “No matter what, let me run.” So Joab said to him “All right, run then.” Ahima’az ran on the road that followed the plain, and he passed the Cushite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was sitting between the inner and outer gates of the city. The watchman went up onto the roof of the gatehouse next to the wall. While he was standing watch, he saw a man running all by himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The watchman called out and told the king. The king said, “If he is alone, he is bringing good news.” The man kept coming and got closer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the watchman saw another man running. The watchman called down to the gatekeeper, “Look! There is another man running all by himself!”
The king said, “This one also is bringing good news.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The watchman said, “The way the first man is running looks like the way Ahima’az son of Zadok runs.” The king said, “He is a good man. He is coming with good news.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahima’az called out to the king, “Peace.” Then he bowed down to the king with his face to the ground and said, “Blessed is the Lord your God, who delivered up the men who raised their hand against my lord the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king asked, “Is the young man Absalom safe?”
Ahima’az said, “I saw a great uproar at the time when Joab sent the other servant of the king and me, your servant. I do not know what it was about.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “Step aside. Stay here.” So he stepped aside and just stood there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Cushite arrived and said, “There is good news for my lord the king, because the Lord has delivered you this day from the power of all who rose up against you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king asked the Cushite, “Is the young man Absalom safe?”
The Cushite said, “May the enemies of my lord the king and all who rise up against you with evil intentions be like that young man.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king was shocked. He went up to the room over the gatehouse. As he was going, he wept and said, “My son Absalom, my son, my son! O Absalom, I wish I had died instead of you. O Absalom, my son, my son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab was told, “The king is weeping and mourning over Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The victory that day became an occasion for mourning for all the people, because that day the people heard that the king was mourning for his son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day the people were sneaking into the city quietly, the way people who are ashamed of fleeing from the battle would sneak in quietly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king covered his face and cried with a loud voice, “My son Absalom, Absalom, my son, my son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab came to the king at the house and said, “Today you have put to shame all your followers, who today have saved your life, the lives of your sons and daughters, and the lives of your wives and concubines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You love those who hate you and hate those who love you. You have demonstrated clearly today that your officers and followers are nothing to you. Today I have no doubt that if Absalom were alive and all of us were dead, you would be pleased.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now get up. Go out. Speak to the hearts of your followers. For by the Lord, I swear that if you do not go out, not a man will remain with you tonight, and this disaster will be greater for you than all the disasters that have come upon you from your youth until now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the king got up and took his seat by the gate. All the people were told, “Look! The king is sitting in the gate.” So all the people came into the presence of the king.
Israel had fled, every man to his own home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people in all the tribes of Israel were quarreling and saying, “The king delivered us from the hand of our enemies. He saved us from the hand of the Philistines. Now he has fled out of the land from Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Absalom, whom we anointed over us, has died in battle. Now why are you silent about bringing back the king?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David sent a message to Zadok and Abiathar, the priests. He said, “Speak to the elders of Judah. Ask them, ‘Why will you be the last to bring the king back to his palace?’ The plan that all Israel has been discussing has been reported to the king at his house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are my brothers. You are my flesh and blood. Why will you be the last to bring back the king?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also said, “Say to Amasa, ‘Are you not my flesh and blood? May God punish me severely and double it, if you are not the permanent commander of my army in place of Joab.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David turned the hearts of all the men of Judah as if they were one man. They sent to the king and said, “Return, you and all your servants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king returned and came to the Jordan. The men of Judah came out to Gilgal to meet the king and to bring the king across the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shimei son of Gera, the Benjaminite from Bahurim, hurried and came down with the men of Judah to meet King David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One thousand men from Benjamin were with him. Also, Ziba, the manager of the house of Saul, came, along with his fifteen sons and his twenty servants. They rushed down to the Jordan ahead of the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They crossed over the ford to escort the household of the king across and to make a good impression on the king.
Shimei son of Gera bowed down before the king when he was crossing over the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He spoke to the king: “My lord, do not consider me guilty. Do not remember the wrong your servant did on the day that my lord the king went out from Jerusalem, and do not take it to heart,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for I, your servant, know that I have sinned. Look! I have come today, the first one from the whole house of Joseph to come down to welcome my lord the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abishai son of Zeruiah answered, “Shouldn’t Shimei be put to death because he cursed the anointed of the Lord?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David said, “What do we have in common, you sons of Zeruiah? For today you are my adversaries. Should any man in Israel be put to death today? Do I not know that today I am king over Israel?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Shimei, “You will not die.” The king took an oath concerning him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth, grandson of Saul, also came down to welcome the king. He had not taken care of his feet or his beard and had not washed his clothing from the day the king departed until the day he came back in safety.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he came from Jerusalem to meet the king, the king said to him, “Why didn’t you go with me, Mephibosheth?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth answered, “Your servant said, ‘Because I am crippled, I need to have the donkey saddled so that I can ride on it and go with the king.’ But, my lord the king, my servant deceived me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has slandered your servant to my lord the king. However, my lord the king is like an angel of God. Do what is right in your eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the house of my father deserved death from my lord the king, but you included your servant among those who eat at your table. What further right do I have to cry out again to the king?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to him, “Why say more about your situation? I say that you and Ziba are to divide the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth said to the king, “Let him take everything, now that my lord the king has come safely to his house.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barzillai the Gileadite came down from Rogelim. He crossed over the Jordan, escorting the king back over the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barzillai was very old, eighty years old. He had provided food for the king during his stay at Mahanaim because he was a very wealthy man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Barzillai, “Cross over with me. I will provide for you as my guest in Jerusalem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Barzillai said to the king, “How many years am I going to be alive? Why should I go up with the king to Jerusalem?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Today I am eighty years old. Can I tell the difference between good and bad? Can your servant taste what I eat and what I drink? Can I still hear the voice of the male and female singers? Why should your servant become a further burden to my lord the king?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let your servant cross over the Jordan with the king for a short distance. Why will the king pay me back with such a reward?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please, let your servant return and die in my own city near the grave of my father and my mother. But look! Here is your servant Kimham. Let him cross over with my lord the king. Do for him whatever seems good to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king said, “Kimham shall go over with me, and I will do for him whatever seems good to you. All that you want from me, I will do for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the people crossed over the Jordan, and the king also crossed over. Then he kissed Barzillai and blessed him. Barzillai then returned to his own home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king went over to Gilgal, and Kimham crossed over with him.
All the people of Judah, as well as half the people of Israel, escorted the king over.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But suddenly all the men of Israel came and said to the king, “Why have our brothers, the men of Judah, stolen you and brought the king and his household over the Jordan, along with all the men of David?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the men of Judah responded to the men of Israel, “It is because the king is closely related to us! Why has this angered you? Have we eaten at the king’s expense? Or have we received anything for ourselves?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The men of Israel responded to the men of Judah, “Ten shares of the king belong to us! That is more of David than you have the right to. Why do you despise us? Were we not the first to speak about bringing our king back?”
But the response of the men of Judah was even harsher than the words of the men of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A worthless troublemaker named Sheba son of Bikri, a Benjaminite, was present. He blew the ram’s horn and said, “We have no share with David, and no inheritance with the son of Jesse. Every man to his own tent, Israel!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the men of Israel deserted David and followed Sheba son of Bikri. But the men of Judah stuck with their king and accompanied him from the Jordan to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David arrived at his palace in Jerusalem. The king took the ten concubines whom he had left to take care of the house and put them in a residence that was under guard. He provided for them but did not go to them anymore. They were confined until the day of their death—a life of widowhood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Amasa, “You have three days to bring all the men of Judah to me and to be here yourself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Amasa went to summon Judah, but he took longer than the time that David had set for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David said to Abishai, “Now Sheba son of Bikri will do more damage to us than Absalom. You take the soldiers of your lord. Pursue Sheba, so that he does not find fortified cities for himself, and we lose him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab’s men, the Kerethites, the Pelethites, and all the elite troops followed Abishai. They went out from Jerusalem to pursue Sheba son of Bikri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they were by the large stone that is at Gibeon, Amasa came to meet them. Joab was wearing his battle dress and had a belt with a sheathed dagger fastened around his waist. As he went forward, the dagger fell out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said to Amasa, “How are you, my brother?” With his right hand Joab grabbed Amasa’s beard to kiss him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Amasa was not on guard against the dagger that was in Joab’s other hand. With it Joab struck Amasa in the abdomen, and Amasa’s intestines spilled out on the ground. It did not take another blow to kill him.
Joab and his brother Abishai resumed their pursuit of Sheba son of Bikri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of Joab’s young officers stood beside Amasa. He said, “Who favors Joab? Who is for David? Follow Joab.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amasa was still wallowing in his blood in the middle of the highway. Someone saw that all the people were stopping when they came upon Amasa and saw him, so he dragged Amasa off the highway into the field and threw a garment over him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Amasa was removed from the highway, everyone followed Joab to pursue Sheba son of Bikri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sheba passed through all the tribes of Israel to Abel Beth Ma’akah, and all the Berites were gathered together and they followed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the men who were with Joab besieged Sheba in Abel Beth Ma’akah. They constructed a siege ramp against the rampart of the city, and they started battering the wall to make it fall down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A wise woman called out from the city, “Listen! Listen! Please tell Joab, ‘Come here and let me speak to you.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He approached her, and the woman said, “Are you Joab?”
He said, “I am.”
She said to him, “Listen to the words of your servant.”
He said, “I am listening.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said, “In former times they always said, ‘Let them ask in Abel.’ That is how they settled things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am one of the peaceful, faithful people of Israel. You are seeking to put to death a whole city that is a mother in Israel. Why do you want to swallow up the inheritance of the Lord?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab answered, “May I be cursed, yes, cursed, if I am here to swallow up or destroy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is not the case. The fact is, a man from the hill country of Ephraim, whose name is Sheba son of Bikri, lifted up his hand against King David. Just give him up, and I will withdraw from the city.”
The woman said to Joab, “Certainly! His head will be thrown over the wall to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the woman went to all the people with her wisdom, and they cut off the head of Sheba son of Bikri and threw it to Joab. Then he blew the ram’s horn, and they dispersed from the city, every man to his tent. Joab then returned to the king in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab was over the whole army of Israel. Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the Kerethites and the Pelethites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adoram was in charge of forced labor. Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was the record keeper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sheva was the secretary, and Zadok and Abiathar were the high priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also Ira the Jairite was a government minister for David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There was a famine in the days of David for three years in a row.
David sought the favor of the Lord, and the Lord said, “There is blood guilt on Saul and on his house because he put the Gibeonites to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the king summoned the Gibeonites and spoke to them.
(The Gibeonites were not related to the people of Israel, but they were a remnant of the Amorites. The Israelites had given them a sworn promise, but Saul had sought to kill them in his zeal for the people of Israel and Judah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to the Gibeonites, “What shall I do for you? How will I make atonement to you so you will bless the heritage of the Lord?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Gibeonites said to him, “The issue between us and Saul and his house cannot be settled with silver and gold. Nor is it up to us to put anyone in Israel to death.”
So David said, “Well then, what are you saying I should do for you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to the king, “From the man who consumed us and who planned to destroy us so that we would have no place in all the territory of Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
we ask you to give us seven of his male descendants. Allow us to hang them up before the Lord in Gibeah of Saul, who was the chosen of the Lord.”
The king said, “I will grant it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king spared Mephibosheth, the son of Saul’s son Jonathan, because of the oath of the Lord between David and Jonathan, the son of Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king took Armoni and Mephibosheth, the two sons of Saul to whom Rizpah daughter of Aiah had given birth, and the five sons of Merab, the daughter of Saul, to whom she gave birth for Adriel son of Barzillai, the Meholathite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David handed them over to the Gibeonites, and they hanged them on the mountain before the Lord. The seven of them died together. They were put to death in the first days of the harvest, at the beginning of the barley harvest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rizpah daughter of Aiah took sackcloth and spread it out for herself near the rock. From the beginning of the grain harvest until rain started falling on them from the sky, she did not allow the birds of the air to come upon them by day nor the wild animals by night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was informed about what Rizpah daughter of Aiah, the concubine of Saul, had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David went and got the bones of Saul and the bones of Saul’s son Jonathan from the citizens of Jabesh Gilead, who had stolen them from the public square of Beth Shan, where the Philistines had hanged them on the day when the Philistines killed Saul at Gilboa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought the bones of Saul and the bones of his son Jonathan from there. They also gathered the bones of the men who had been hanged.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they buried the bones of Saul and Saul’s son Jonathan in the land of Benjamin at Zela in the tomb of Kish, Saul’s father. They did everything the king commanded. After that, God responded to the prayers for the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: War occurred again between the Philistines and Israel. So David went down with his troops and fought against the Philistines. David became very tired.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishbi Benob was one of the descendants of Rapha the giant. His bronze spear weighed more than seven pounds, and he was equipped with a new weapon. He said that he was going to kill David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abishai son of Zeruiah came to David’s aid. He attacked the Philistine and killed him. Then David’s men swore to him, “You are not to go out to battle with us anymore, so that you do not put out the lamp of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, there was another battle with the Philistines at Gob, in which Sibbecai the Hushathite killed Saph, who was also descended from Rapha the giant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was yet another battle with the Philistines at Gob. Elhanan son of Jair, the Bethlehemite, killed the brother of Goliath the Gittite, whose spear shaft was like a weaver’s beam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was war again in Gath. There was a very tall man who had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot, twenty-four in all. He also was descended from Rapha the giant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he taunted Israel, Jonathan son of Shimeah, the brother of David, killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These four were descended from Rapha the giant in Gath. They fell at the hand of David and his servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David spoke the words of this song to the Lord on the day when the Lord had delivered him from the grasp of all his enemies, even from the grasp of Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said:
The Lord is my rocky cliff,
my stronghold, and my deliverer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My God is my rock. I take refuge in him.
He is my shield and the horn of my salvation,
my high fortress, my refuge, and my savior.
You save me from violence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I call to the Lord, who is worthy of praise,
and I am saved from my enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The waves of death swirled around me.
Floodwaters of destruction rolled over me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The ropes of the grave wrapped around me.
The traps of death threatened me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In my distress I called to the Lord.
To my God I cried out.
He heard my voice from his temple.
My cry for help reached his ears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the earth shook and quaked,
and the foundations of the heavens trembled.
They shook because the Lord was angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Smoke rose from his nostrils,
and fire out of his mouth devoured.
Coals were set on fire by it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he tore open the heavens and came down.
A dark cloud was under his feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He rode upon a cherub, and he flew.
He soared on the wings of the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He made the darkness around him his shelter,
the dark rain clouds of the sky.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From the brightness in front of him, coals of fire burned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the Lord thundered in the heavens.
The Most High raised his voice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he shot his arrows and scattered the enemy.
He hurled great bolts of lightning and routed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the sources of the sea were revealed,
and the foundations of the world were uncovered
    by the rebuke of the Lord,
    by the breath of wind from his nostrils.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He reached down from on high and took hold of me.
He drew me out of deep waters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because they were too strong for me,
he rescued me from my powerful enemies,
from those who hate me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They confronted me on the day of my disaster,
but the Lord supported me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he brought me out into a wide open space.
He rescued me because he delighted in me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord has dealt with me according to my righteousness.
According to the cleanness of my hands, he has repaid me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because I have kept the ways of the Lord.
I have not done evil and departed from my God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So all his just decrees remain before me,
and I have not turned away from his statutes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have been blameless with him.
I have kept myself from guilt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord has repaid me according to my righteousness,
according to the cleanness of my hands in his sight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To the merciful you reveal yourself as merciful.
To the blameless person you reveal yourself as blameless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To the pure you reveal yourself as pure,
but to the crooked you reveal yourself as crafty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, you save humble people,
but your eyes are on the proud, and you bring them down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, you are my lamp, O Lord.
The Lord turns my darkness to light.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For with you I can charge against a battalion,
and with my God I can jump over a wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This God—his way is blameless.
The speech of the Lord is pure.
He is a shield for all who take refuge in him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For who is God besides the Lord?
And who is the Rock except our God?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This God wraps me with strength
and makes my way smooth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By making my feet like those of a deer,
    he enables me to stand on high places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because he trains my hands for battle,
    my arms can draw a bronze bow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then you give me the shield of your salvation.
Your response makes me great.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You widen the path under my feet,
so that my ankles do not give way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I pursued my enemies, and I destroyed them.
Yes, I did not turn back until they were wiped out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I wiped them out. I crushed them.
They could not rise again.
They fell beneath my feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You wrapped me with strength for battle.
You made those who rose up against me bow down to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You made my enemies turn their backs and flee.
I destroyed those who hate me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They cried for help, but there was no one to save them.
They cried to the Lord, but he did not answer them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So I ground them as fine as dust of the earth.
I scattered them and trampled them down like mud in the streets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You delivered me from the accusations of my people.
You preserved me as the head of nations.
A people I did not know serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Foreigners cringe before me.
As soon as they hear me, they obey me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Foreigners fall exhausted.
They come trembling from their strongholds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord lives! Blessed be my Rock!
May God, the Rock who saves me, be exalted!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This God, who avenges me, subdues peoples under me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You delivered me from my enemies.
Yes, you exalted me above those who rose against me.
You rescued me from the violent man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, I will thank you among the nations, Lord.
To your name I will make music.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By providing great salvation for his King,
he shows mercy to his Anointed One,
to David and to his Seed forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These are the last words of David,
the oracle of David, the son of Jesse,
the oracle of the man raised up high,
the man anointed by the God of Jacob,
the pleasant singer of Israel’s songs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Spirit of the Lord speaks by me.
His word is on my tongue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The God of Israel has spoken.
To me the Rock of Israel has said,
“The one who rules over people with righteousness,
who rules in the fear of God,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
he is like the light of the morning when the sun rises,
like a morning without clouds,
like brightness after rain, which produces grass from the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But my house is not like this with God.
Nevertheless, he has made an everlasting covenant with me,
    completely ordered and secure.
Certainly he will make it spring up for my salvation, to fulfill my desires.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Worthless, wicked men are all like thorns to be thrown away.
No one even picks them up with his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Anyone who touches them uses an iron tool or the shaft of a spear.
They are completely burned up in the fire, right where they are.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These are the names of the elite warriors of David:
Jashobeam son of Hakmon was leader among the Three. He lifted up his spear and killed eight hundred at once.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After him came Eleazar son of Dodo, the Ahohite. As one of the three elite warriors, he was with David when they defied the Philistines gathered there for battle. The men of Israel retreated,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but he took a stand and struck down the Philistines until his hand got tired and froze to the sword. The Lord brought about a great victory on that day. The people of the army returned to Eleazar but only to strip the fallen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After him came Shamma son of Agee, the Hararite. The Philistines were gathered at Lehi. In that location there was a parcel of land full of lentils. The people fled from the Philistines,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but Shamma took his stand in the middle of that parcel of ground and defended it. He struck down the Philistines, and the Lord brought about a great victory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three of the Thirty went down and came to David at the Cave of Adullam at the time of the grain harvest. A band of Philistines was camping in the Valley of Rephaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was then in the stronghold, and the garrison of the Philistines was in Bethlehem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David expressed a deep craving, “Who will give me water to drink from the well of Bethlehem, which is by the gate?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the three elite warriors broke through the camp of the Philistines and drew water from the well of Bethlehem, which is by the gate. They took it and brought it to David, but he was not willing to drink it, so he poured it out to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “May I be cursed, Lord, if I would do this. This is the blood of the men who went at the risk of their lives!” He would not drink it. These are the things the three elite warriors did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abishai, the brother of Joab, the son of Zeruiah, was the leader of the Thirty. He wielded his spear against three hundred, all of whom were killed. His reputation equaled that of the Three.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In fact, he was praised more than the Three, and he became their commander, but he did not belong to the Three.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada, an energetic warrior from Kabze’el, performed great deeds. He struck the two Lions of God from Moab. He also went down and killed a lion in the middle of a cistern on a snowy day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He killed an impressive Egyptian, who was armed with a spear. Benaiah went down against him with a staff, snatched the spear from the hand of the Egyptian, and killed him with his own spear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the accomplishments of Benaiah son of Jehoiada. His reputation equaled that of the Three.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was praised more than the Thirty, but he did not belong to the Three. David placed him over his bodyguard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Among the Thirty were:
Asahel, the brother of Joab,
Elhanan son of Dodo from Bethlehem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Shammah the Harodite,
Elika the Harodite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Helez the Paltite,
Ira son of Ikkesh from Tekoa,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Abiezer from Anathoth,
Mebunnai the Hushathite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Zalmon the Ahohite,
Maharai the Netophathite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Heleb son of Ba’anah the Netophathite,
Ittai son of Ribai from Gibeah in Benjamin,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Benaiah a Pirathonite,
Hiddai from the ravines of Ga’ash,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Abi-Albon the Arbathite,
Azmaveth the Barhumite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Eliahba the Sha’albonite,
the sons of Jashen,
Jehonathan,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Shammah the Hararite,
Ahiam son of Sharar the Ararite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Eliphelet son of Ahasbai
the son of the Ma’akathite,
Eliam son of Ahithophel the Gilonite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hezro the Carmelite,
Pa’arai the Arbite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Igal son of Nathan from Zobah,
Bani the Gadite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Zelek the Ammonite,
Naharai of Be’eroth, the armor bearer of Joab son of Zeruiah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ira the Ithrite,
Gareb the Ithrite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Uriah the Hittite.
In all there were thirty-seven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The anger of the Lord burned against Israel again, and he incited David against them so that he said, “Go count Israel and Judah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to Joab, the commander of his army, “Travel through all the tribes of Israel from Dan to Beersheba and register the fighting men. Then I will know how many there are.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said to the king, “The Lord your God will make the people a hundred times larger, however many they may be, and the eyes of my lord the king will see it. But why does my lord the king have such a strong desire to do this?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the word of the king overruled Joab and the commanders of the army. So Joab and the commanders of the army went out from the presence of the king to register Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They crossed the Jordan and camped in Aroer on the south side of the city that is in the middle of the canyon. Next they went to Gad and then to Jazer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they came to Gilead and to the land of Tahtim Hodshi. After that, they came to Dan Ja’an and around to Sidon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they came to the fortress of Tyre and all the cities of the Hivites and the Canaanites. After that they went out to the Negev of Judah at Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they went throughout all the land, and then came back to Jerusalem at the end of nine months and twenty days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab reported the numbers from the registration of the fighting men to the king. Israel had eight hundred thousand soldiers who could draw a sword. Judah had five hundred thousand men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David had a guilty conscience after he had counted the fighting men. So David said to the Lord, “I have sinned greatly in what I have done. But, Lord, please take away the guilt of your servant, because I have acted very foolishly.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David got up in the morning, the word of the Lord came to Gad the prophet, David’s seer. The Lord said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go tell David, ‘This is what the Lord says. I am laying out three choices before you. Choose one of them for yourself, and I will carry it out against you.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Gad went to David and told him about this. He said, “Shall seven years of famine in your land come upon you, or three months of fleeing with your enemies pursuing you, or three days of plague in your land? Now consider this and decide what answer I should return to the one who sent me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Gad, “This puts me in a difficult position. Please! Let us fall into the hand of the Lord, for his mercy is great. But do not let me fall into the hands of man.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord sent a plague against Israel from the next morning until the appointed time. Seventy thousand people from Dan to Beersheba died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The angel stretched out his hand toward Jerusalem to destroy it, but the Lord relented and did not bring the disaster. He said to the angel who was carrying out the destruction among the people, “Enough. Now hold back your hand.”
The angel of the Lord was near the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to the Lord, as he was watching the angel striking the people, “Look! I am the one who sinned. I am guilty. But these sheep—what have they done? Please! Let your hand be against me and against the house of my father.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gad came to David on that day and said to him, “Go up and build an altar to the Lord on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David went up and obeyed Gad’s instructions as the Lord had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Araunah looked up and saw the king and his servants coming toward him. So Araunah went out and bowed down to the king with his face to the ground,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and he said, “Why has my lord the king come to his servant?”
David said, “To purchase the threshing floor from you, in order to build an altar to the Lord, so the plague will be held back from the people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Araunah said to David, “My lord the king can take it and offer whatever seems good to him. Here are oxen for the burnt offering, as well as the threshing sledges and the yokes of the oxen for the wood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O King, Araunah is giving all this to the king.” Araunah also said to the king, “The Lord your God will accept you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the king said to Araunah, “No. I insist on purchasing it from you for what it is worth. I will not offer to the Lord my God burnt offerings that I did not pay for.”
So David purchased the threshing floor and the oxen for fifty shekels of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built an altar to the Lord and offered burnt offerings and fellowship offerings there. The Lord heard the requests for the land, and the plague was held back from Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator
